Award.AwardTitle: Singularities and Collapsing in G2 Manifolds
Award.AbstractNarration:
Manifolds are a mathematical way to describe various spaces arising from applications. This project focuses on a special class of manifolds called G2 manifolds. These 7-dimensional spaces play a vital role in theoretical physics, particularly in the so-called M-theory. Besides their physical interest, G2 manifolds provide a rich geometric structure, an ideal setting to study beautiful and deep interactions between objects arising in different parts of geometry such as Riemannian and spin geometry, submanifold geometry, and gauge theory. Since G2 manifolds are odd-dimensional, the methods of complex geometry cannot be applied directly, unlike the case of Calabi-Yau manifolds, which are the 6-dimensional counterpart appearing in string theory of theoretical physics. As a result, the current understanding of G2 manifolds is limited. Additional difficulties arise from the fact that the G2 manifolds of interest to M-theorists must contain special points that mathematicians call singularities. Inspired by one of the expected physical dualities between string theory and M-theory, the project aims to develop a new construction of G2 manifolds and explore its consequences. The key idea is to relate G2 geometry to the better understood Calabi-Yau geometry through the phenomenon of collapsing: the aim is to construct 7-dimensional G2 manifolds that look very close to Calabi-Yau manifolds of one lower dimension.

The expected physical duality between Type IIA string theory and M-theory compactified on a circle can be interpreted geometrically as the existence of sequences of compact G2 manifolds collapsing to Calabi-Yau three-folds. Non-compact examples of these collapsing phenomena have appeared in the physics and mathematics literature since the early 2000s. The project aims to study these complete examples more thoroughly and use them as local models for the behavior of compact G2 manifolds in various gluing constructions. Goals of the research project are: (i) to develop a new construction of compact G2 manifolds close to a Calabi-Yau 3-fold collapsed limit; (ii) to extend the construction to produce the first known examples of compact G2 manifolds with isolated conical singularities; and (iii) to study the smoothing theory of these singular G2 manifolds and exhibit examples of "geometric transitions" in G2 geometry analogous to flops in Calabi-Yau geometry. Besides the rigorous mathematical verification of expectations in M-theory, success in achieving these goals would potentially generate more diffeomorphism types of compact 7-manifolds known to admit a torsion-free G2 structure, advance understanding of complete non-compact Ricci flat manifolds in higher dimensions with interesting asymptotic geometries beyond the asymptotically conical and asymptotically cylindrical case, and contribute to understanding of the boundary of the moduli space of smooth G2 manifolds. As a lower-dimensional analogue of these constructions, bubbling phenomena occurring in sequences of Ricci-flat metrics on K3 surfaces collapsing to lower-dimensional limits will also be studied.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project focused on codimension-1 collapse and singularity formation in special holonomy. Manifolds with special holonomy are some of the most important objects in differential geometry and play a vital role in theoretical physics as geometric models for particle physics and as spaces of vacua of quantum theories.

A unifying transversal theme of current research is the study of degenerations of manifolds with special holonomy: geometrically, we aim to understand all special holonomy metrics on a given space and transitions between different geometric spaces through singularities; analytically, this study involves understanding the behaviour of solutions to the partial differential equations describing the holonomy reduction as we vary parameters; physically, geometric degenerations correspond to and explain dualities between different physical theories.

The particular type of degenerations that have been the focus of the project involve sequences of manifolds with special holonomy collapsing to a space of one lower dimension, like a sequence of thin doughnuts becoming a circle in the limit. The study of collapsed degenerations of special metrics is a challenging and very active area of research in geometric analysis. The particular focus of the project on codimension-1 collapse was partially motivated by a fundamental duality in theoretical physics, the one between M-theory and Type IIA String Theory. 

In dimension 4, the lowest possible dimension for special holonomy, we gave a general construction of sequences of so-called hyperk?hler metrics collapsing to a 3-dimensional flat limit. This result is part of a series of recent breakthroughs by various authors on the collapsing geometry of 4-dimensional special holonomy and Einstein metrics. This recent activity shows how much there is still to say about the geometry of K3 surfaces, very classical objects such as the zero locus of a homogeneous polynomial of degree 4 in 3 (complex) variables, studied by geometers since the 19th century!

This low-dimensional result and its ingredients have then served as a prototype and guiding principle for the construction of a plethora of new examples of complete non-compact manifolds with special holonomy in dimension 7 and 8 (so-called G2 and Spin(7) manifolds), the least understood cases of manifolds with special holonomy. The collapsing perspective has allowed us to exploit classical and very recent results about the geometry of lower dimensional spaces (self-dual Einstein 4-orbifolds and Calabi-Yau 3-folds) to produce new significant results in these elusive higher dimensional geometries. In particular, before our work only a handful of complete non-compact G2 and Spin(7) manifolds was known (all essentially known since 1989): we were instead able to produce infinitely many new such examples with interesting asymptotic geometries, infinitely many distinct families of such structures on the same underlying space, families of examples depending on an arbitrarily large number of parameters, and in special cases with a large symmetry group classify all possible examples and study their behaviour in families. Further exploitation of these new results in geometry and physics is being actively pursued by various groups of researchers.   

Throughout the project, an intense programme of presentations at national and international institutions has allowed us to advertise the results, techniques and ideas of the project to different communities of researchers across mathematics and physics. Lecture mini-courses, research visits and the compilation of a survey paper have created multiple opportunities for the training of graduate students and young researchers.
